revised_title: Neural Control of Locust Walking: A Distributed Consensus Model
tldr: The author conducted experiments on locusts to study the neural control of walking. They found that walking is initiated by many neurons acting in consensus, rather than a single command neuron. The type of walking output is determined by the "across-fibre pattern" of all the inputs to the pattern generators, providing flexibility and adaptability in the behavior. This alternative to the command concept suggests that walking is controlled by a distributed system of neurons working together.
scientific_discipline: Biology and Life Sciences > Neurobiology and Behavior
